description.text: This is a simplified version of the (Taranis) case bottom (made by Nebbian) for the 4-in1 module. After printing the original one (in ABS) and the release tabs broke off the first time I squeezed them and the screw holes just crumbled. So I redesigned it from scratch to use less plastic, stand up to more abuse, and take less time to print. It works great! Note: this remix uses Nebbians original cover.

Anet A8

No

Supports:

No

.1

100%

Notes:

print it in ABS, for the flexibility. Also: I print everything at .1mm myself, but I don't see why this couldn't be printed at lower resolutions.

among the images I have included, one is of my failure with Nebbians design that inspired me to make this remix. Note: I made the box a little bit shallower than the original one to save plastic and time, and it actually made it a lot easier to plug the box into the taranis with the antenna already mounted. BONUS

Printed with ABS. I would not use any plastic lower than ABS as far as heat tolerance. I used brim on all the parts.Your milage may vary. I mounted mine on standoffs but springs can be used I think. Print 4 of adjuster knobs and adjuster bolts. Print 2 of the corner braces and corner brace mirrored. Supports are only needed for the corner braces.

Get lost dog clips...

I hate dog clips. Period. Always having to watch where they're at especially when doing a large print. I found these and did a remix for my P3steel (Migbot I3) and my Anet A8 in Tinkercad. These are designed for those of you who have the 220x220 MK3 heatbed AND a 220x220x4mm borosilicate glass plate. The brackets are mounted so they are .5 to 1mm below the glass so the hot end won't run into them. Just mount 'em, align the glass with your bed and tighten carefully. As far as I know, these should work with any bed and glass as long as they're the same size and use countersunk m3 bolts. NOTE: If going onto a P3Steel, you may have to do a little filing as mine barely makes it between the frame when the bed is moving. Also, when you heat the bed up to 90c or higher the first time, I would check to make sure everything is still tight and the glass isn't loose. FYI: I haven't taken the bed temp beyond 100c, so I can't confirm the reliability of these clamps at a higher temp.

description.text:
I made this in 3D Builder to connect Rocket Pig Games Tilescape dungeon flooring. I did this to save time and filament. Printing the floors frames would have taken so long. Dozens of these connectors can be printed in just minutes VS hours and days if I was printing the Tilescape frames. If you find that they are a hair loose or tight just + or - a percent in your slicer program. I also reduced the flooring thickness 25%, 5mm to 3.75mm to save time as well.

Enjoy!

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

40%

Notes:

Currently working on a way to use walls like this.

Dark filters for your telescope!

In astrophoto it's a real relief (and sometimes almost a necessity) to automate your captures. Some are using filter wheels. This design is to make your evenings even easier - it allows you to simply mount the printed item in a filter cell holder (1.25" or 2") and mount it in your filter wheel. You are then able to take darks whenever you want and even have your imaging software do this automatically!

Designed to work with normal filter holders. I bet you've got some useless filter holders lying about. If not, TS-Optics sells them with article number "Filterfassung1".

27.5mm diameter and 2mm thickness for the 1.25" version and 47mm diameter and 2mm thickness for the 2" version.

description.text:
Here is a slimline case for a Samsung Galaxy S7 smart phone. Designed from scratch, it fits like a glove, and the slim walls don't add much to the overall size of the phone. It keeps it as compact as possible, while still being well protected.

We have dropped ours repeatedly on hard ground with this case, and while the cases are a little worse for the wear, the phones remain undamaged.

If printed in ABS, I would recommend scaling up by 0.7% to allow for shrinkage (i.e. 100.7%)

If you're having bed adhesion problems or curling, select the model with the brim and cut it off after printing

Note: This is for the Galaxy S7 only, it will not fit the S7 Edge

comments.text: Will s7 edge fit?
comments.author: Clwebb

comments.text: Doubtful.  It may fit the top and bottom if they are the same layout as the normal S7, but I think the sides will stick up above the curved sides that the Edge has.  You could print one up, and maybe file down the sides if the rest of it fits OK.
comments.author: Clwebb

comments.text: I think it needs to me 1 mm longer to fit, I am getting 5.6" on a set of calipers, FYI.
comments.author: wweiser

comments.text: My S7 also measures 5.6" on the calipers.  As mentioned in the description, depending on the material you are using, you may need to scale up a bit to allow for shrinkage.  I printed it in ABS at 100.7%, to allow the usual 0.7% shrinkage that ABS seems to have and it fits perfectly.  I scale all of my ABS prints up by 0.7% and they seem to come out pretty true to size that way.  I rarely print in PLA, but from what I've read, it doesn't suffer as badly from warping or shrinkage.
comments.author: wweiser

comments.text: I used PETG, and when I laid a 5.6 " block down inside the case in an Editor, it was hanging out over the edge, adjusted the length by 1mm works great on my remix.
comments.author: rmcniff

comments.text: Do i have to scale if i use pla
comments.author: Furkan03

comments.text: If you print in PLA, I would not scale it.  PLA has low enough shrinkage that it shouldn't matter.  ABS on the other hand seems to consistently shrink about 0.7% for me.

This adapter and code was created to be able to motorize a cheap, common, filter wheel. Normally this requires a lot of plates, adapters and big stepper motors which add more and more weight. They also have bigger power requirements.

By printing a small adapter and replacing a threaded insert you can get a low weight, direct driven, filter wheel with good positional accuracy and homing features for a considerable cheaper cost (my total is £40) than just buying something off the shelf.

The source code for the Arduino and ASCOM-driver, as well as a setup for the driver, is located here: https://github.com/Pipshag/MilkyWheel

Below follows quick instructions:
This repository contains both the Arduino as well as ASCOM code (and compiled driver) to be able to motorize a Filter Wheel, often used in Astrophotography.

Material:

  • Filter Wheel (this design uses a no-name filter wheel labeled "Multiple 5-Filter Wheel")
  • Arduino Nano (for low weight)
  • 28BYJ-48 5V stepper motor (able to run off the USB-connection)
  • ULN2003 shield (often included with the stepper)
  • Hall sensor US5881LUA (for autocalibration)
  • 3D Printed Direct Drive adapter
  • 3D Printed Wheel Cover

Build:

  • Wire accordingly
    -- Connect 28BYJ-48 with stepper cable to ULN2003
    -- Pins digital 8, 9, 10, 11 to ULN2003 pins IN1, IN2, IN3, IN4
    -- Pin digital 12 to Hall Sensor (data)
    -- Pin 5V and Ground to ULN2003 5V+ and Ground
    -- Pin 3.3V and Ground to Hall Sensor (Positive and Ground)
    -- Connect 10K resistor on Hall Sensor between Positive and Data

Remove the two center screws and two hex screws on the back side. Remove back plate. In the center of the filter disc you'll see a threaded insert, remove this. Take the 3D printed adapter and make sure it fits. Also make sure your stepper motor axle fits inside the adapter hole. Then, remove the adapter and use some CA-glue on the outside of the adapter before inserting it fully. I used some Accelerator to make it bond really well. Don't use glue for the stepper shaft since you might probably want to remove the front disc one day. Assemble everything again and then mount the stepper by pushing it inside the adapter. I glued the Hall Sensor on the opening of the case and used a small neodymium magnet which I glued to the center disk after getting a good position with my Arduino.

Open the Arduino ino file and check the settings. Calibration offset is a good way to make sure you can get a great 0 position even if things change mechanically over time.

Hall Sensor Wiring with Pullup resistor:
"To use connect power to pin 1 (all the way to the left), ground to pin 2 (middle) and then a 10K pull up resistor from pin 3 to power. Then listen on pin 3, when the south pole of a magnet is near the front of the sensor, pin 3 will go down to 0V. Otherwise it will stay at whatever the pullup resistor is connected to. Nothing occurs if a magnet's north pole is nearby (unipolar)."

Pin 1 is the pin to the left when the Hall Sensor is resting with the flat side on a table.

This is an educational robot intended to be used as a sniffer or line follower.
It has been designed to attach other components such as servos, LEDs, push buttons, a buzzer, and other sensors included in the product "Mi primer kit de robotica" ("My first robotics kit") distributed by bq.

• 1 x chassis
  • 1 x battery holder
  • 2 x wheel
  • 1 x sniffer

    Hardware:

  • 15 x M3x10 screw
  • 2 x M3x40 screw
  • 16 x M3 nut
  • 2 x 3x50mm O-ring
  • 8 x AAA batteries

    Parts included in "Mi primer kit de robotica" by bq:

  • 1 x Freaduino UNO (Arduino UNO derivative)
  • 2 x IR sensors for line following
  • 2 x continous rotation servo
  • 1 x 8 AAA battery holder
  • 1 x Bluetooth Module (optional)

    Build Instructions

    See the attached pdf (in Spanish). Pictures are clear enough to follow the steps even if you do not understand Spanish.
    Check this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hQF05l-RxTo

    Example code

    Attached you will find a simple Arduino program for following a line ("Arduino_renacuajo_line_follow.ino").

    Android-Control

    Now you can control your robot through the "RoboPad" app.
    So just upload the "Arduino_robopad_renacuajo.ino" into your robot, connect the Bluetooth Module and install the Android app:
    https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.bq.robotic.robopad&hl=en
    Youtube trailer: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=F8OlUu4fgNo

title: Air Compressor Muffler / Silencer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a muffler for an air compressor. We have a compressor at the office that is quite loud. Did some research and found you can buy these for around $40 US. Designed this to be similar. The photo is of the first version, the stl files are of the next version; didn't expect as much vibration as there was. Once we attached it the noise was considerably less.

The assembled canister (two Muffler Bodies and one Muffler Plate is put in line with the intake on your compressor with a 3/4 1/2 inch NPT pipe fitting. I've attached the Fusion 360 file archive as well so you can make any needed modifications easier.

I printed all three pieces together with the NPT threads nearest the plate. It should print okay with no supports due to the chamfered edges.

Printer:

Folger Tech Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2125

Infill:

15%

Notes:

May need to print a little more stoutly than we did. The vibrations are considerable.

Assembly

Take one muffler body and apply acetone (if using ABS to print) to all the top surfaces. Place the muffler plate in line with the marks on the muffler body. Then do the same to the other muffler body, keeping the marks in line with each other. Clamp the whole thing together. You may need to apply a little acetone or sealant around the seam to ensure air tightness.

comments.text: Thanks for creating this.

comments.text: You are absolutely correct. I measured the inside of the model to get the size. I found a website that lays out the NPT fittings more clearly for tech people like me. Apparently, a 1/2 inch pipe is .84 inches on the outside. Nice catch! http://machiningproducts.com/html/NPT-Thread-Dimensions.html

title: Parametric Robot Wheel (Biohazard)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: NOTE: This has been upgraded to a much more flexible version that incorporates all previous designs and adds lots of new features. The new version is here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:21486 I always thought the biohazard logo would make a good robot wheel... So this biohazard-inspired parametric robot wheel that uses an o-rings as a tire. I've uploaded the fully-commented OpenSCAD file, and with it, you can specify the o-ring you're using, plus define lots of parameters like thickness, rim height, hub diameter/height, shaft diameter, number of set screws, and even fillet/chamfers on the hub. You can even add your own design by changing the spoke() module. See instructions for details on the renderings, and the OpenSCAD file. Wheel Designs using the same foundation: Biohazard: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:21010 Circles: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:21065 Spoked: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:21064 Spiral: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:21277 ...and more in the works!

For details on modifying the OpenSCAD file, scroll down. Otherwise, keep reading. The STLs are named with the motor shaft size, and the o-ring cross-section diameter (CS) and internal diameter (ID). For example, "BiohazardWheel-4mm-7CS-95ID" is rendered for a 4mm motor shaft, with an o-ring that has a cross section diameter of 7mm and an internal diameter of 95mm. Fractional numbers are probably metric equivalents of SAE units. (See below for details.) In some cases, I've set the "stretch" parameter, which stretches the tire out a bit for a tight fit. Here's how to use these wheels: 1) Print the part. 2) Drill out the motor shaft hole and the set screw hole for a perfect fit. 3) Push an M3 nut into the captive nut trap with a soldering iron. (If you don't want to do this, you can change the nut diameter and thickness in the OpenSCAD file for an easier fit.) 4) Put the tire on the wheel, and the wheel on the robot. 5) Watch carefully and see if your robot is cool enough to adapt to having only one wheel. Do you know of any common and inexpensive o-ring sizes? If so, please let me know so I can create STLs for them! Here's what I have so far:

  • BiohazardWheel-4mm-7CS-95ID: 4mm, 7mm, 95mm. This is the size I happened to have on hand. This is the one shown in the photos.

  • BiohazardWheel-4mm-4.76CS-149.23ID: 4mm, 5-7/8", 3/16". This seems to be a popular size on ebay.

  • BiohazardWheel-4mm-2.38CS-55.56ID: 4mm, 2 3/16", 3/32". This is another size I found on ebay. I set this one to chamfer the top and leave the bottom of the hub alone.
    • Modifying the OpenSCAD File There are a number of parameters you can use to get just the size you need. The OpenSCAD file will also echo out some helpful calculations for you. O-Ring Tire Parameters: Often wheels are built around the tires. In this section, specify the properties of te o-rings you're using as tires.

  • tireCSDiameter - ring cross-sectional diameter (CS) -- How thick is the o-ring rubber?

  • tireID - O-ring Internal diameter (ID) -- How wide is the inside opening?

  • tireStretch - O-ring circumferential stretch percentage (usually 0-5%) -- How much to you want to stretch it to get it on?
    • Other general wheel properties: These properties define other general wheel metrics. Because I wrote this to build a number of different wheel types, you'll see properties like "numberOfSpokes." You can change the code in spoke() to create any spoke design you want.

  • wheelWidth - The width (or thickness) of the the wheel.

  • rimHeight - The height of the rim portion of the wheel. (Must be greater than tire CS radius.)

  • numberOfSpokes - Number of "spokes." Leave this at three if you're doing the biohazard design
    • Hub properties: These properties define the hub -- or how the wheel connects to the motor. The default values for the captive nut are precise for a M3 nut and will make the nut a very tight (if not impossible) fit. I prefer this because it allows you to "melt" the nut into place with a soldering iron. However, if you don't have a solder iron or prefer a looser fit, then just adjust the nut diameter and thickness. Similarly, the holes for the motor shaft and grub screw are also precise. This allows the holes to be drilled out for a more precise fit. Again, you can adjust these to suit your needs. The hubZOffset can be used to "sink" the hub into the wheel, and it defaults to half the wheel thickness. For example, when the hubHeight is 10 and the hubZOffset is -2, then the hub will protrude 8mm from the wheel, but the shaft hole will be 10mm deep. The set screw will still be positioned in the middle of the exposed vertical height, and the fillet/chamfer will also be rendered in the correct position. This property is also useful if you want to poke a hole entirely through the wheel. (e.g. If the wheel is 6mm thick, set the hub height to 16 and the hubZOffset to -6, and you'll get a hub that protrudes 10mm from the wheel surface with a hole that extends all the way through the wheel.)

  • hubDiameter - The diameter of the hub portion of the wheel

  • hubHeight - The height of the hub

  • shaftDiameter - The diameter of the motor shaft

  • setScrewDiameter - The diameter of the set screw. 3 is the default for an M3 screw.

  • setScrewNutDiameter - The "diameter" of the captive nut, from flat to flat (the "in-diameter")

  • setScrewNutThickness - The thickness of the captive nut

  • setScrewCount - The number of set screws/nuts to render, spaced evenly around the shaft

  • hubZOffset - The Z position of the hub, negative numbers from the surface of the wheel

  • baseFilletRadius - The radius of the fillet (rounded part) between the hub and wheel.

  • topFilletRadius - The radius of the fillet (rounded part) at the top of the hub.

  • chamferOnly - Set to true to use chamfers (straight 45-degree angles) instead of fillets.

title: Top mounted filament guide for Wanhao i3/Maker Select

description.text:
Why?

When the filament is mounted on the control box (which is safer and more stable than mounting it on top of the Z bridge) the filament grinds against the frame and can cause under-extrusion.

This filament guide is optimized for use with the spool on the control box.

Features

  • Mounts using existing holes on the Wanhao i3 V2.1 and probably all recent Maker Select models

  • The filament hole is beveled outwards to provide a smooth path from all directions

Open source

The original design (fusion360) is included, so feel free to improve it.

Requirements

Requires 2x M5 bolts with a threaded length of at least 10mm.
Longer is possible, but be wary of your Z-clearance!

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Printed in PETG, but PLA should work equally well.

comments.text:
TWO M5 ! Nothing like a well bolted filament guide ! Can be used as transport handle !
Gee, not one single day without a plethora of filament guides and spool holders. Looks like it is a huge market :)
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
Considering the fact that the top has two pre-tapped M5 holes in it, I figured using M5's (even if a bit overkill) was the most logical way to go.
As far as the originality goes: it's a quick design for myself that I decided to share, for free of course. The fusion360 file is included with full history so everyone interested can roll back the steps and see how it was made. Hopefully this will help at least a couple people design their own filament guides or spool holders ;)
Strangely enough it already has 26 downloads, which is much more than my "niche" designs so yes, I'd say there is indeed a market for it...

author: elephantman

title: Testing Column for different Extruder Temperatures

description.text: After slicing this 10cm high column change the extruder temperature in the GCODE file after 10mm travel in the Z axis. Examine the print and determine the best extruder temperature for the filament you are currently using. The printed columns can be stored and used as reminders if the same filament is used in the future. After several statements out of the community indicated that the original file was corrupt I have uploaded another version, hopefully less prone to slicing failures. Please read the comments below and check out Deoryp's remix of the file (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:211514) to avoid unsatisfactory results.

comments.text: the way you have it numbered in the original also gives you definte temp transition so teh difference should be EXTREMELY Clear I like it as is

No offense, de_baseggio, I am just providing information. Perhaps you will inspire a version without the myriad geometry problems.

description.text:
I made this Popsocket mount because I wanted to be able to hang up my phone in lots of places without having to spend $10 per mount! I've included the .blend file in case you want to add holes for screws, ziptie anchors, etc. Should be easy to modify.

UPDATE 20170215: I made a video demonstrating how it works... https://youtu.be/S2TqTaZhznE

Printer:

Original Prusa i3 MK2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Print it with supports so that the overhanging part comes out OK. I printed it with a 0.2mm layer height with a 0.4mm nozzle on an Original Prusa i3 MK2 in eSun Blue PETG.

IMPORTANT NOTE FOR MOUNTING IN CARS: If you plan to use thing in your car make sure you print it in PETG, ABS, or other similar heat-resistant plastic. PLA will melt!

I recommend at least 25% infill to make sure the part stays reasonably strong. It should print OK in PLA, PETG, ABS, etc. It doesn't need to flex (the Popsocket is what flexes). I made it to print flat but you can probably print it without (as much) supports if you print it upright.

Tic Tac Toe (auch: Drei gewinnt, XXO, Kreis und Kreuz, Dodelschach oder engl. Noughts and Crosses) ist ein klassisches, einfaches Zweipersonen-Strategiespiel, dessen Geschichte sich bis ins 12. Jahrhundert v. Chr. zurueckverfolgen laesst.  
Auf einem quadratischen, 3x?3 Felder gross?en Spielfeld setzen die beiden Spieler abwechselnd ihr Zeichen (ein Spieler Kreuze, der andere Kreise) in ein freies Feld. Der Spieler, der als erster drei Zeichen in eine Zeile, Spalte oder Diagonale setzen kann, gewinnt. Wenn allerdings beide Spieler optimal spielen, kann keiner gewinnen, und es kommt zu einem Unentschieden. Das heiss?t, alle neun Felder sind gefuellt, ohne dass ein Spieler die erforderlichen Zeichen in einer Reihe, Spalte oder Diagonalen setzen konnte.

title: OpenForge Cut-Stone OpenLOCK Angled Flat Ends

description.text:
Continuing out OpenForge support of OpenLOCK, we have here Cut-Stone Angled Flat Ends.

For instructions on how to get started with OpenForge, take a look at our tutorials.

OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our:

title: π64 (mini N64 RetroPie case)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
UPDATE: 5/16/2017
Stemming from KyleARectors idea to use the game cartridge to house a cooling fan, I have added a new game cartridge to the build files that is designed for a 30mm x 30mm x ≤10mm fan to mount onto the bottom. I designed it to fit the Raspberry Pi fan sold by Adafruit (https://www.adafruit.com/product/3368) but any fan of the same size will fit. The mounting holes are sized for M2.5 screws.

UPDATE: 4/3/2017
I didn't realize that the link to the microSD extension was actually the wrong extension cable.
My apologies to everyone who bought the wrong cable because of my mistake. The link listed below is now the correct one.

Inspired by all of the brilliant RetroPie cases out there, I decided to create a new one based on my favorite video game console from my childhood. I give you the π64!

First off I must give credit where it is due.
• Bruno Amaral created an excellent model from which I started. You can find it here: https://grabcad.com/library/nintendo-64-console-1
• Thanks to my friend Andrew Holt for printing the parts for me on his FlashForge Dreamer.
• Thanks to my friend Jared Larsen for doing the soldering.

I wanted this to look and function as close to the original as possible. The case is built to house a Raspberry Pi 3 model B. Since the original N64 console has a door on top to access the expansion memory I made this the access for the microSD slot with the use of an extension cable. It has a functioning reset button and the power switch has a slot to accommodate a switch although I decided not to put one in my case. To use a reset switch a small amount of soldering does need to be performed on the PI. The original N64 console has a red power LED on the front. Rather than wiring in an LED I experimented with a fiber optic line that pipes the light from the power or processor or both LEDs to the front of the console. The light pipe idea works surprisingly well. I am quite satisfied with the results over all.
If you’re not into games you can always use your Raspberry Pi as a Kodi media player or anything else you like.

Required parts:

• 3D printed parts shown above (If you want to print the case in the proper colors I recommend the following filaments or you can print them in white and paint them like I did. All model units are in millimeters.)
For the console: Dark Grey filament from 3DPrima, http://www.3dprima.com/en/filaments-for-3d-printers/pla-175mm/primaselect-pla-175mm-750-g-dark-grey.html.
For the game cartridge and controller ports: Earl Grey filament from Faberdashery, http://www.faberdashery.co.uk/products-page/print-materials/earl-grey/

• Raspberry Pi 3 model B with power cord and video cable

• 8GB microSD card with software installed, https://www.raspberrypi.org/downloads/noobs/, https://retropie.org.uk/download/

• 7, M2.5 screws 6mm long (#3 1/4in long screws will also work)

• Super glue

Optional parts:

For relocating microSD port:
• MicroSD extension cable, http://www.ebay.com/itm/TF-To-Micro-SD-TF-Flex-Zip-Extension-Cable-Adapter-for-GPS-DVD-Mobile-Phone-TW/131878023354?_trksid=p2045573.c100505.m3226&_trkparms=aid%3D555014%26algo%3DPL.DEFAULT%26ao%3D1%26asc%3D41451%26meid%3Da58424d4c10747dc8454a0a44f50975f%26pid%3D100505%26rk%3D1%26rkt%3D1%26 (remove the casing from the port end)

For installing a reset switch:
• A standard PC reset switch, http://www.ebay.com/itm/ATX-PC-Computer-Motherboard-Power-Cable-Switch-On-Off-Reset-Computer-Replacement-/360774703348?hash=item53ffd918f4:g:TWkAAOSwnDZT~faO
• A 2 pin male header soldered into the holes labeled “run” on the Pi board, http://www.mouser.com/ProductDetail/Harwin/M20-9990246/?qs=Jph8NoUxIfWjw4WmyRvzag%3D%3D&gclid=CPLXg-zOhtICFRKRfgodGTsFUg (you can swipe one from any old computer motherboard)

For piping the LEDs to the front of the case:
• A short length of 1.8mm clear plastic cord, http://www.michaels.com/stretch-magic-bead-jewelry-cord-1.8mm-x-3m/10315671.html#q=bead+cord&pmpt=qualifying&sz=24&start=25

For installing a power switch:
• I’m afraid you’re on your own, but I did leave a cutout for a switch.

For the console and game labels:
• Print the included PDF at 100% scale. Labels look best when printed on photo paper.
• Thanks to "bobotrax" for creating the alternate game label.

Enjoy building your own!

Check out my other 3D print projects on my Shapeways page, https://www.shapeways.com/shops/optimal-inceptions

remixed_from.title: 43.33:1 Compound Planetary Gearset, NEMA 17 Mount, No Hardware

title: 43.3:1 Compound Planetary Gearbox For Robotic Arm Project!

description.text:
Updates!

4/27/17-Made another version of this with a higher gear ratio.
https://youtu.be/8H3fbxzmF9w

Where's Everything Else???

  • This gearbox has an newer, nearly identical twin, with the same form factor and different gear ratio, it can be found in the collection
    https://www.thingiverse.com/Gear_Down_For_What/collections/robotic-arm
    In This Collection you will find:
    • All other related parts for this project
    • Future Updates to this Project
    • All User Submitted Remix's
    • Click that watch button to get notifications on future uploads!

Assembly

Align the planet gears in order as shown in the main picture, insert a sun gear, Snap Ring Gear #1 on, Inset all sun Gears, snap the other 2 or 3 ring gears on, also, you will need to close the gap in the rings before you spin this gear set or else it could skip teeth and get out of alignment, for this i have included the ring closures, that fits over all the rings

Compatibility

  • This Gearbox is 100% compatible with the Robotic Arm Project!
  • This Gearbox can be used in any application that the 66:1 Gearbox is used in, because the outside of the rings gears, and the width of the ring gears are identical.
  • Do not mix and match gears between this Gearbox and the 66:1.

How it works

  • When you rotate the one piece sun gear, The Planet gears orbit that gear, when the Planet Gears make a full 360 Degree rotation around the Sun Gears, Ring Gear #2 and Ring Gear #4 will move 27.7 Degrees, ( 2 Teeth)

  • The other important thing to realize here is that Ring Gears #1 & #3 will be at the same potential and Ring Gear #2 & Ring Gear #4 will be at the same potential

  • The use of Ring Gear #4, the 4 Module Planet Gears, and Sun Gear #4 is optional and used to increase the amount of torque this gearbox can transfer, as well as to decrease the amount of load on each gear, think of it like a door hinge.

Other Important Info:

CAD Files??

The most recent version of this project can be downloaded in lots of different formats from this link: http://a360.co/2wW8PDX

Show Your Work!
  • Make a "make" and show everyone what you made! (make? :0) Everyone will thank you for it!

For More Cool Projects and Upgrades, Don't forget to Follow Me on Thingiverse and Subscribe to my Youtube Channel

Gear Down For What?

title: Customizable Yin-Yang Fidget Spinner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Customizable Yin-Yang Fidget Spinner

update 2017-09-29
Allow for ISO 4032 M10 (16mm) and M12 (18mm) hex nuts along with the old DIN 934 M10 (17mm) and M12 (19mm)
update 2017-6-26
add option to r\educe "tail" size
update 2017-04-11
added the option to use loose ball bearings: 3/8", 1/2", and 5/8" (tested with 5/8"); for a heavy, long spinning spinner.
update 2017-04-06
corrected a design flaw with larger weights that caused insufficient connection between the bearing frame and the weight frames
update 2017-03-28
allow for additional types of weights: 3/8", 1/2", M10, M12 hex nuts, 4 X penny, 3 X nickel, 5 X dime, 4 X quarter
update 2017-02-13
eliminated bug that prevented M8 nut option from working correctly

Important!

When using Customizer, a radius > 0 will cause the preview to time out, but if you press the Create Thing button, Customizer will create it!

  • uses hex nuts or bearings as weights
  • uses 1- 608 (22x7) bearing to spin
  • uses 2-4X M8 or 5/16" hex nuts, 608 bearings or 3/8", 1/2" or 5/8" loose ball bearings for weights

Customize:

  • edge roundness (radius)
  • which weights: bearings or hex nuts
  • the number of peripheral objects (yin-yang)
  • The rotation angle of the peripheral objects: 2, use small, around 120; 4, use large, around 160-170

Note:

  • The all bearing options require a large hand for a one-handed spin (Sorry, Donald)
  • See my collection of all of my fidget spinner designs.

title: Prusa i3 heated bed cable strain relief

description.text: This is a simple strain relief for heated bed wiring on Prusa i3 style printers. This particular design requires you to drill 2 3mm holes through the aluminum bed to mount so do not proceed unless you are willing to modify your print bed. I recommend countersinking the drilled hole and using phillips head machine screws to attach, especially if you have auto leveling you don't want your head hitting hex heads during print. IF you notice in my picture I currently have it attached with hex head screws as I am out of countersink heads, and it limits the print area to the front of the bed so the head does not impact the screw heads. other than that it is working perfectly.

remixed_from.title: Printed y-carriage for prusa i3, fits 200x200

title: Fully Printable Y carriage on 200x200 bed with bearing IGUS STYLE

description.text:
I decided to make this remix because it is very difficult to align the 4 bearings so that the Y axis slides easily. I have included an extended LM8UU bearing that comes from the IGUS STYLE http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:24990 printed on PLA, and I have adapted the bearing housings to be able to install the 100mm LM8UU.
I add the proyect file for Sketchup. You can edit It.
Heat bed size for this Y carriage must be 200x200 (most common hotbed)

Print the Y carriage and the bearing housings like your favourite config. I print the Y carriage with a 0.24 layer heigh and a 0.4 nozzle, 40% infill. And the bearing housings the same but 100% infill.

The bearing must be printed with a external perimetral line of 1mm (Slic3r - Print settings - Advanced - External perimeters = 1) and a 0% infill, a layer heigh can be from 0.1 to 0.2.
And very important, print slow.
Thats my config with a 0.4 nozzle and the size is perfect.

*11/02/17 -
Internal part of the LM8UU (100mm) bearing edited so that the contact surface is the same as an original bearing (Less friction). And fixed for be printed without supports or layer fan.

comments.text: To make such long bearing is a big mistake as it increase the friction. Plus the bearing surface must be pretty bad.To align two short bearings mounted in a carriage or even mounted apart  is not a problem, just use the proper tools, reamer, a smooth rod or drill bit plus abrasive paper, heated smooth rod etc...
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: I have been testing PLA bearings for several days and I have to say that friction is very low compared to cheap aliexpress bearings. You are right in that these long bearings have a greater friction compared to the standard measurement. description.text: This is a RAMPS 1.4 to Melzi adapter. It is split in two parts to be easily printed.

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Feel free to use your own settings.

Preparation

To easily fit the part onto the mounting posts, you might need to widen the two holes (of each part) a bit. The mounting posts have a width of 5.5mm but the powder coating can add up to 5.6mm.

Assembly

  1. Step
    Due to the arduino's layout you can tighten up the PCB only with three M3 screws (see picture). To secure it in place, I used three M3x10 countersunk head screws at the back of the adapter. They are as high as the PCB and prevent it from turning around. Longer screws are possible, but pay attention to the other boards added on top of the arduino.

  2. Step
    Use normal M3x10 screws and plastic washer to screw the arduino to the adapter.

  3. Step
    Set the part onto the mounting posts and secure them with the original screws.

description.text:
Wanted to model something in OnShape similar the baby toy called Rock-A-Stack. Basically a stacking toy, for rings of decreasing diameter. This is for my 16 month old to play with, and was another opportunity for me to learn more in OnShape.

I used 3 shells for the base, and created a hole from top to bottom of the shaft. The purpose was to give more strength to the shaft, and try to prevent the shaft from shearing off at the base layer. With those shells, and a hole going all the way to bottom of the part, I believe it will be a stronger shaft.

description.text:
This is a holder for the Minn Kota i-Pilot remote. The remote also fits in updside down (see pictures). You may ask why would I want to use the i-pilot upside down? Well, that way if you press left the boat goes left when sitting in reverse direction.

Mounting:
4 screws or 2 cable ties

If you print this, please give me feedback if it's strong enough for your needs.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

z < 9mm @ 30%, z>=9mm @ 100%

Notes:

I used the "Swap at Z 1.1" plugin for cura to change the infill setting at z=9mm to 100%. Thereby I get robust clips without wasting filament on the bigger, lower part.

Edit: I changed the z-value from 11mm to 9mm after one of the clips broke off after the remote holder fell down from low height with the remote attached to it.

I printed this in PLA but I think ABS would be a better choice.

title: Pi Zero Action Cam Case For A Drone

description.text:
The case was designed by myself to house a Pi Zero and Pi cam, it's held together by four M3 Bolts, it has space for two miniature buttons, and hole on top to hold an LED to signal recording.

The script used can be found here: http://www.cya.nyc/2015/04/raspberry-pi-action-camera/

The case is to be mounted on a quad copter so no battery was needed. A hole for a power supply lead was left out of the design as the size would be a personal preference.

I upgraded my Pi Cam using a 1/3rd inch CCTV camera lens adapter allowing for a greater feild of view, detailed in this post: http://wiki.raspberrytorte.com/index.php?title=Camera_Module_Lens_Modifcation

remixed_from.author: capitaenz
remixed_from.title: Prusa Hotbed Cable Guide with cable tie

description.text:
This is a cable strain guide for an Anet A8 hotbed cable.

My plug was beginning to burn out as the connector plug was not a tight fit, and so I soldered them directly to the hotbed. I made this cable guide to stop solder movement. It mounts to the H aluminium frame underneath the hotbed, and to make this work I had to rotate the hotbed left 90 degrees and mounted it just past the bearing.

The cables are a tight fit, but tightening the cable management spiral allowed it to slip through the gap. If its too loose for your wires then you can use a small cable tie to tighten further.

The aluminium H plate was 3mm and this piece was a tight fit there as well printed with ABS.

remixed_from.author: Kouruu
remixed_from.title: Reach 3D Titan Extruder Mount and Prox Sensor

title: Reach3d Proximity Sensor Mount for Titan

description.text:
I wanted to have the option to have the proximity sensor on the front, closer to the hot end. This also makes using the Titan Extruder very compact, and it's very simple to mount to the gantry.

Instructions:

Use the Reach3d Titan Mount created by Kouruu, found here:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1977341

The instructions for mounting to the Gantry are different. Here are the steps:

  1. Keep the v-wheel and 1/4 spacer from the original Reach3d kit. You will use all of them.
  2. You will need one M5 25mm screw for the lower right, since it butts up against the holder.
  3. I used M5 30mm screws for all the other screw holes, but you can use longer ones if you want.
  4. The screws go in order (from back to front): screw, v-wheel, 1/4 spacer, Reach3d belt idler holder, Titan 3d Printed Extruder Mount, then the nut.

I ended up hot gluing my x limit switch to the side of the motor, left of the top left nut. It seems to work fine that way. At some point I plan to design something that will fit under the nut. The stock limit switch holder that comes with the Reach3d is a little too wide to fit.

Print Settings:

I recommend printing with supports. This model is a little tricky to print. I may come up with another design that doesn't require supports that can use bridging. But I was in a hurry to get my extruder working. I have included the Open SCAD file that I threw together in case you want to try tweaking it. Please post a remix if you do!

Settings that I used:

"#define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 25 // X offset: -left +right [of the nozzle]"
"#define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0 // Y offset: -front +behind [the nozzle]"
"#define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0 // Z offset: -below +above [the nozzle]"

I have the newer / updated motor and used the following settings for the steps (837 is the one I changed from the default reach settings):
"#define DEFAULT_AXIS_STEPS_PER_UNIT {78.74,78.74,406,837}"

title: MP Select Mini 4DM Side Panel Relay Adapter

description.text:
I was in the process of adding the 4th Dimension Modifications Enhanced Side Panels, along with the extended bed heater, bigger power supply and bed power relay board. The switches for accessory power were interfering with the installation of the power relay, so I designed the adapter that would move the bard about an inch to the left, clearing the switches.

In addition to printing this adapter, you'll need 4 M3 - 6mm and 4 M3 - 8 mm screws and 4 M3 nuts. I used nylon for their no-conductive quality.

author: falconman

title: Gopro / Karma Grip backpack strap / shoulder mount

description.text:
I just dropped almost £600 on a gopro hero 5 and karma grip, and refused to pay the extra £180 for the magic gopro backpack.

This is my answer! Its a simple gopro mount that slips under the webbing you will find on the shoulder straps of most military style backpacks (like my trusty every day backpack). Designed for the karma grip, but there is no reason this can't carry any other gopro mountable object.

Print at super high infil if you value your camera, no supports necessary, and remember that the mount Is designed to be printed in something TOUGH. I used taluman alloy 910 which worked a treat.

Now get out there and film stuff!

title: LoPro 164 Mini Quad for up to 3.75" props

description.text:
Meet v1 of the LoPro 164 mini quad for up to 3.75" props. This is my first frame design, so I thought it would be best to share it with you guys. The frame is a low profile design, optimizing battery position for better center of gravity. The frame has a 6mm depth and counterbored holes for bottom screws. The mid plate allows for a 850 mah 3s or 4s battery, but I should push back the XT30 plug for a little more room (note revised V2 mid plate). This design is for 1306 or 1407 motors, and the frame offers a little bit of protection for them. There are mounting holes for both flight controller sizes, so you can run an ultra low setup with arm mounted escs, or do a short stack with a 4in1 like I did.

I printed the main frame with Raptor PLA at 90% triangular infill. Baked at 215 degrees for 10 minutes for max strength. Its not very light– I would need to continue tweaking infill percentage to dial in a more lightweight option. Seriously, this frame seems bombproof though.

Components used in the build–

-RCX 1306 3200kv
-Racerstar 20A V2 4in1
-FuriousFPV Radiance
-DSMX Lemon diversity
-Hawkeye 200mw VTX
-Eachine 1000tvl cam
-Cam mount here - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1110726
-TrueBlood antenna flex mount - get from RMRC
-xt30 power connector and plate - get from Banggood (don't have to use)
-Gemfan Nylon 3545 props - I have a few different kinds to try. A slightly cut down 4" prop might work well.
-Standoff lengths used in photos– 20mm between main frame and mid plate, 35mm in front, and 13 between mid and top plates.

I will try to get the quad out this weekend for a maiden flight and some DVR FPV. Please, if you decide to print this frame, post your photos so I can see your builds! If you have any suggestions about the frame, please let me know. I'd love to hear back from you guys who can experiment with an optimal infill percentage for the best possible strength to weight ratio. I hope you enjoy!

UPDATE (02/11/17) – Maiden flight is linked below. A few notes about my personal build– 3.5 inch props definitely have more thrust than 3 in, but the motors are surely pulling more current. It flies smooth and balanced, but I need to tune my D settings to soften up the sticks. I need a little more space to fly before really opening up the throttle. Until then, more balanced props should take care of the cam vibration. I don't care for the Gemfan Nylon 3545 props– they seem fragile and unbalanced. I think cutting down DalProps V2 4045 (efficient) props might be a better solution (gotta try my tri-blades).
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M6bk6dnnM-s&feature=youtu.be

UPDATE (02/13/17) – I trimmed down a Dalprops 4045 v2 to 3.75" and it just barely fits inside the back of the frame. I will need to relocate the zip tie antenna mount in order for the prop to fully swing past the frame. I have not flown these props yet, but they seem way more efficient than the bullnose 3.5". I posted a photo so you can see the prop clearance.

UPDATE (03/07/17) – I made some modifications to the mid plate with the V2 release. The antenna ziptie mounts have been moved forward, allowing for more prop clearance (for 3.75" props). The XT30 battery plug mount has been moved backwards to allow for more battery space. The mid plate thickness is the same as V1, but I decided to print it at 3mm for slightly more strength. Lastly, I posted another photo of the LoPro with DalProps V2 (efficient) 4045 tri-blades cut down to 3.75." It was raining today, so I didn't have a chance to fly. Hopefully I can provide some more DVR footage soon. I just received some Nylon Alloy 910 filament and intend to test a lower infill frame print.

UPDATE (03/28/17) – I was able to get out and rip around a larger property with the LoPro. It is quite nimble at high speed but still need to tune a bit. I will print a PETG frame this week and load it up with 4000kv red bottoms. See the FPV clip below–
https://youtu.be/ab0Oe-vOBUg

UPDATE (04/16/17) – LoPro rebuild complete. The frame was printed in Nylon Alloy 910 for extra strength and lower weight due to optimized infill (60% triangular). Nylon was dyed and then baked for 10 hours at 170 degrees F. Militia Brothers 3530 props, a direct solder antenna, and RS1306 4000kv motors round out the build. It feels at least 25-30 grams lighter than the first build. I hope to maiden it Easter weekend.

UPDATE (04/16/17) – Maiden flight went well with better PIDs and rates adjustment. I still need to tweak a few things here to smooth stick movement. The incorrect cam color is based on a new lens I am trying out (2.5). It does not have the little glass piece on the back of the lens like the original that comes with the 1000TVL. I will replace this glass piece to fix the color. The motors offer smooth power.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=pXOblt_CiUI&feature=youtu.be

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1800

Infill:

90% triangular for max strength, try less for lower weight

Notes:

I am trying this frame out with the RaptorPLA stuff. It seems very solid after baking, with a tiny bit of flex. I would not recommend regular PLA for this frame design. ABS and Nylon should work well. Use supports for screw holes under the frame. Do not add support to the motor screw holes.

Courtesy of Brian Smith, note the last few photos listed In the gallery. He printed with carbon fiber PETG, 4 perimeter layers at 20% triangular infill, .14 layer height. The main frame came in at 49 grams. He mentions that the CF PETG is a bit dense, so I am sure we can get the weight down a bit more with a high strength nylon print.
Designed on Fusion 360

comments.author: andimon

comments.text: I use the Attitude V3 Fatsharks and they seem to work pretty good with the 1000tvl. They don't have a wide aspect ratio, so I am not sure I can comment how the 1000tvl will look with your Dominators. Maybe the aspect ratio can be manipulated by your goggles if need be. I have the 1000tvl on 5 quads so I can say that I do like them for the cost. It has a larger CCD sensor and can mount in multiple ways (different frames). I think it comes standard with a 2.1mm (may be wrong here), which I find to be perfect for racing and moving at faster speeds. I put a 2.5mm and 2.8mm on this cam (various other quads), which do work well for more freestyle flying, as you are able to see more of your surroundings. It does not have a mic built in, though, but for $13 bucks, you can't beat it. I'd say give it a go and see what you think. There should be enough room at the front of this frame to mount many other CCD or CMOS cams, but you will need to drill out mounting holes.

title: Fitting parts test for FDM Machine

description.text:
This is a fitting parts test to test the tolerances of your printer. Its not the exact shape of a jigsaw puzzle piece but it made to determine the tolerance of 3 kinds of surfaces that FDM printers might have problems with. It has a straight edge, a rounded edge and a sharp acute angle bend. It takes little filament to print and should help you determine the kind of allowance you need to give when designing your parts.

Made entirely in onshape. You can create a free account and customise it here if needed.

author: someoneonly

description.text:
Yea, I know I'm a bit late for the spirit of the holidays, but here's a reindeer cable wrap for your iPhone or iPad. The base is measured perfectly for the Apple charger. I tested on both the old iPhone cables and the new ones, works for both.  
Once you pass the USB cable through and plug it into the charging base, this thingy stays on without any help. I've demonstrated that with one of my pictures where I'm holding it by just one antler.  
It would be great if someone paints it and uploads their makes. Would love to see them  :-D

Unfortunately, the thing needs to be printed in 3 pieces. No supports are needed.  
Print the face at .1 mm resolution, and the others can be printed in .2 mm resolution. The whole thing took about 50 min total on my Replicator 2.  
After you're done printing, the face and antlers are inserted into the base. It's pretty straightforward to understand. I included the model of the whole piece so you can see how it looks when it's done. You can even potentially use this model on a floating UV cured liquid resin printer if you have one.  
You can use superglue to hold everything in place, however when I printed it and slipped the parts into their slots, I could no longer take them out anymore. The face, I could slip out with some pressure, but the antlers were impossible to take out once I put them in. So in other words, I really don't think you need superglue.
